title: Firefox memory usage with Facebook
content:
After using Facebook Watch on Windows 10 for a while, Process Explorer will show one Firefox Process with a huge amount of memory, which takes up to two minutes of high processor usage to be released once the tab is closed. This problem has been around for a long time. Just thought I'd see if anyone has any ideas other than not watch FB videos.

content:
I have to say that this has been the most frustrating issue that I have been unable to find any kind of help with.

I am running W7 on this laptop (I do not know more than that), even W10 on my desktop, both with the most updated version of mozilla.

I have removed the adobe flash player, and now I cannot get any videos to play, like on CNN and other various sites. I just get the spinning wheel of nothing. It seems that only you tube is working, barely.

Am I missing something, is this open html5 crap supposed to just take over and everything will be okay.

Maybe someone, somewhere can post a layman's explanation on what is going on. If there are issues, how to fix them. I don't need anymore information telling me how to remove because it is dead. What I need is what is replacing it, how does it work, and where and what can I do to fix issues.

Searching for help here on this subject is just tedious. I get over 3000 replies, or what ever they are called here, but just nothing on an explanation of what is changed and or how it works, more like doesn't work.

What do I need to do in order to be able to watch/play videos online.

Any help would be very, very much appreciated.

Thanks in advance.

title: Recent Mozilla changes
content:
I just want you to know, due to your decision to go political with...

"In a blog post titled ‘We need more than de-platforming’, the open-source software community said that Twitter’s decision to permanently ban Trump from its platform didn’t go far enough in weeding out “hate” on the internet. While blaming Trump for the “siege and take-over” of the US Capitol on January 6, the non-profit tech group argued that “white supremacy is about more than any one personality.”

“We need solutions that don’t start after untold damage has been done. Changing these dangerous dynamics requires more than just the temporary silencing or permanent removal of bad actors from social media platforms,” Mozilla wrote."

I've used firefox across multiple platforms for years but you've lost me and quite a few of my friends - I let them know of your decision to play politics and join the censors and jackboots who fail even to research before they trumpet how politically correct they are.

Strange how you never murmured as domestic terrorists burned, looted and murdered people for MONTHS!

I doubt you will leave this up - the left loves to remove anything that isn't blind worship of their beliefs.

title: I felt very sorry for myself
content:
I have been a Firefox user for many years and I recommend everyone to use it. I was happy that the program was free and not run by a company because I knew there was no policy behind it. A browser that allowed you to go online and be comfortable.

Today I heard that a "stupid" in Mozilla said that censorship of Trump is not enough and we must stop him and his supporters! "We need more than de-platforming."

This was from a company that claimed to be non-profit. And it bothered me

First of all, you parasitic woman Mitchell Baker, who are you to stand in front of millions of Trump supporters? You do not even dare to comment on the nonsense you wrote. You did not give an email address to hear the defenses of Trump supporters there. Because you probably love Kamala Harris Black Butt, you are not allowed to use Firefox and the Internet against us.

Secondly, it is not up to you whether people want to be racist or not. It is good that racism is not even a crime. Biden's son is a pedophile. Why were you silent about this? You do not have the right to to decide how people think.

Why does a software company comment on policy and think it should take action?

I will remove Firefox forever today, but before that I want to say that you are tarnishing the name of free software. May God curse you all.

title: Checksum for FIrefox ESR 78.6.1 - Software Supply Chain Security
content:
With concerns about supply chain security, I would like the ability to ensure that the file download matches a recognized checksum.

Downloading from: https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/78.6.1/releasenotes/ yields checksum SHA256 55249C4861FE521CB32D72785481A146B64812AF2ECE7341FAAA5C79ABC0F395

This does not match any of the checksums available at: https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/firefox/releases/78.6.1esr/

Best practice would be to publish the official checksum along with the release notes.

Is there another way to close the loop on this?
creator: linden1
